ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Various philosophies on how journalism operates, influences, and persuades depending on the author, region, and style

This is by far my favourite class that I have taken at Yale. It is a really exciting analysis into the role of the journalist when covering conflict. It includes lots of cool guest speakers and by the end of the discussion, your opinion will almost always have been changed!

I learned about the journalistic methods of reporting on conflict. Each week, we focused on how a particular conflict was reported on. In all, I gained insights on ethics of intervention in wartime reporting, the role of the journalistic, and the macro-level goals that journalism should strive to attain.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The seminar format provided for high engagement and the instructor posed highly relevant and interesting questions during each discussion that allowed me to walk away with perspectives that completely opposed my initial thoughts.
I loved the reading assignment structure. I loved the discussions. I thought the guest speakers were always surprising. I really loved it!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Prof. Wood has thoughtfully designed this syllabus to address critical questions about conflict journalism. Some weeks may be reading heavy but Prof. Wood is conscious of that and encourages students to read for understanding rather than completion.
Yes, if the student is interested in learning about the nuances of wartime journalism and would like to expand their perspectives on how reporting operates and influences.

I would recommend this course to any student wanting to take a deep dive into the methods of wartime reporting and their various strengths and weaknesses. I'm sure students who are interested in the relationship between the government and the media and the goal of obtaining objectivity in journalism would love this course.
